tossups.question: For most of the 1960s, the definitive textbook on this behavior was the work of Irving Bieber. This behavior was criticized in a 1956 book by Edmund Bergler, who called its practitioners "injustice collectors." Evelyn Hooker's groundbreaking 1957 paper noted that there was no mental difference between people who did or did not engage in this behavior. People who exclusively demonstrated this behavior were ranked 6 on a scale named for a zoologist at Indiana University. The first objective textbook on it was an 1897 work by Havelock Ellis. Until 1974, people exhibiting this behavior were classified by the American Psychiatric Association's DSM as mentally disordered. For 10 points, the Kinsey Report concluded that what type of sexual behavior was far more common than assumed?
tossups.answer: homosexuality [or same-sex relationships; or gay behavior; or LGBT behavior; or lesbian behavior] <Cheyne>

tossups.question: Adherents of this faith were heavily divided after the 1980 "Glacier View" event, a five-day conference in Colorado. That meeting led to the Australian Desmond Ford having his credentials revoked and leaving this faith. It helped introduce the modern concept of breakfast cereal, as the founder of Kellogg's Cereal was a devoted member, and this faith's emphasis on healthy eating is one of the reasons why Loma Linda, California, has a high longevity rate. Its doctrine of "investigative judgment" holds that God has been performing the divine judgment of Christians since 1844. Emerging out of the Millerite movement, this faith holds the writings of Ellen White to have special authority, exceeded only by the Bible. For 10 points, name this religious group that believes Saturday is the Sabbath.

Chris Freiling argued that this statement is false because it is equivalent to the negation of his axiom of symmetry. It's not the axiom of choice, but Gödel's constructible universe was introduced to demonstrate the consistency of this statement, which was shown to be independent of Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory by Paul Cohen using the technique of forcing, for which he won a 1966 Fields Medal. A reformulation of this statement says that the first beth number is equal to the first aleph number, or alternatively, that the number of reals is aleph-one. For 10 points, identify this assertion in set theory that states that there are no sets whose cardinality is strictly between that of the integers and that of the real numbers.

This man was appointed governor of Higüey (ee-GWAY) after leading a successful campaign against the natives of the region. Woodrow Wilson had a hypothesis about this man and a variety of brown tea. He may have been a deckhand on the second of Columbus's voyages and supposedly discovered the Gulf Stream. This man launched one expedition in search of the island of Bimini. Rumors of gold led him to establish the colony of Caparra, the first European settlement in Puerto Rico. A territory discovered by this man was named for Easter flowers. This explorer was killed by a poisoned arrow from an Apalachee Indian that was shot near the Caloosahatchee River. For 10 points, name this man who "discovered" Florida while supposedly searching for the Fountain of Youth.

A painting of silhouettes of this color, People Begin to Fly, echoes a photograph of the artist leaping from a building's second story. The Monotone Symphony was played at a "Living Brush" exhibit in which nude women smeared themselves with paint of this color to create Anthropometrie paintings. That International shade of this color was used in the work of Yves Klein. A painting subtitled "Souvenir of Biskra" depicts a nude of this color and was created by Henri Matisse. Many horses of this color were painted by Franz Marc who, with the painter of many Improvisations and Compositions, founded a movement named for a figure of this color. For 10 points, Wassily Kandinsky founded a movement named for a "rider" of what primary color?
tossups.answer: blue [accept IKB or International Klein Blue] <Brownstein>

tossups.question: During a campaign, this candidate launched an attack ad against his opponent's use of handlers that asked, "They'd like to sell you a package. Wouldn't you rather choose a president?" Rumors about his supposed psychiatric treatments were spread by strategist Lee Atwater. Referred to as a "card-carrying member of the ACLU," this man was slammed for a lack of emotion when responding to journalist Bernard Shaw's question about the hypothetical rape and murder of his wife. He was the subject of the negative ads "Revolving Door" and "Weekend Passes," the latter of which used an image of black convict Willie Horton to paint this man as soft on crime. For 10 points, name this Massachusetts governor who lost the 1988 presidential election to George H. W. Bush.

Percy Shelley wrote a "Discourse on the Manners of the Ancient Greeks" to accompany his translation of this work. This work describes Penia's seduction of the drunken Poros, resulting in the conception of a god who serves as a spiritual intermediate between the divine and the mortal. A man in this work recalls an upward mental progression beginning with the conception of a single beautiful object and culminating in the conception of absolute beauty, which was described to him by Diotima of Mantineia. In this work, a parable in which three sexes of eight-limbed humans are split in two by Zeus is related by Aristophanes at a party hosted by Agathon. For 10 points, name this Platonic dialogue featuring a series of discourses on the nature of love.

The glaucoma drug timolol is also used to prevent heart attacks and these events. The MBA type of them was formerly attributed to spasms of the basilar artery. People with CACNA1A mutations have weakness in half the body during these events. One model of these events posits successive waves of depolarization, ischemia, and vasoconstriction, and is called cortical spreading depression. These events are often treated using agonists of the 5HT-1B and and 5HT-1D receptors, called triptans. Their acephalgic (ay-suh-FALL-jik) type only involves the scintillating scotoma or other auras that classically precede these events, and people suffering from these events are often sensitive to both light and sound. For 10 points, name these severe headaches.
tossups.answer: migraine headaches [prompt on headaches or auras until they are read] <Mukherjee>

tossups.question: A character who lives in this province envisions traveling with Banga on journeys to the sun and the moon. Amrah, a servant girl who lives in this province, fends off people who want to foreclose on her master's estate by pretending to be a ghost. In this province, a man orders Aphranius to commit murder by asking him to provide protection to the victim. Miriam and Tirzah, the mother and sister of a resident of this province, are cured of leprosy during a thunderstorm. In this province, a man avenges himself on Messala by winning a chariot race. It's the setting of the historical and religious narrative interspersed with the action of The Master and Margarita. For 10 points, name this Roman province, the setting of Ben-Hur, which is governed by Pontius Pilate.

In this symphony, a sustained E major harmonium chord plays over a solo violin melody that Henry Louis de La Grange dubbed this symphony's "love theme." A children's chorus follows a "surge in E major" by the trombones and trumpets that introduces the "accende lumens sensibus" theme of this symphony. A loud E-flat major organ chord introduces the first part of this symphony, which is a setting of the "Veni creator spiritus" hymn. Its second part is based on Goethe's Faust. The composer's friend Emil Gutman coined the nickname of this symphony after witnessing 858 singers and 171 musicians play the piece at its premiere in Munich. For 10 points, name this symphony by Gustav Mahler written for the title number of performers.
tossups.answer: Symphony of a Thousand [or Mahler's Symphony No. 8] <Belal>

tossups.question: One of these figures was said to erect pillars with vaginas on them in places that surrendered to him too easily. These figures eat gods that were butchered by the lion-headed deity Shezmu, according to a "cannibal hymn" first addressed to one of these figures called Unas. These people had a wolf's tail pinned to them in a ceremony that may have replaced their outright ceremonial murder by priests, the Sed Festival. Protection of these people was symbolized by a vulture and a uraeus serpent, representing the "Two Ladies" Nekhbet and Wadjet, who also names an "eye" that symbolizes both these people and their patron, Horus. For 10 points, name these people analogized to Horus in life and Osiris in death by the Pyramid Texts found in their tombs.
tossups.answer: Pharaohs [or kings of Egypt; or rulers of Egypt; prompt on the dead] <Golfinos>

tossups.question: After massacring unarmed prisoners of war in this country, Horace West and John Compton were put on trial. For perceived passivity in this country, John Lucas was replaced by Lucian Truscott, much to the approval of Winston Churchill. A general was second-guessed for his slowness in breaking through the Gustav Line in this country and for later choosing to take the capital instead of trapping Albert Kesselring's Tenth Army. Mark Clark was criticized for his decision to bomb a historic abbey in this country. American forces participated in Operation Husky, a 1943 attack on an island belonging to this country. For 10 points, the Battles of Anzio and Monte Cassino occurred in what European country during World War II and helped pave the way for Allied occupation of Rome?
tossups.answer: Italy [or Italian Republic; or Kingdom of Italy; or Italian Social Republic; or RSI; or Republic of Salo] <Cheyne>

tossups.question: The Bouc–Wen model can be used to describe non-linear systems that exhibit this phenomenon. The power lost by this phenomenon can be determined using Steinmetz's equation. The I–V curve of a memristor displays a "pinched" form of this phenomenon. Rolling resistance in tires occurs mostly because rubber exhibits this phenomenon. Degaussing is unable to completely remove remanence (REM-uh-nence) due to this behavior. In systems that display this phenomenon, motions in domain walls lead to jumps in magnetization in the Barkhausen effect. For 10 points, name this phenomenon commonly observed in ferromagnets in which the state of a system is dependent on its history.

In 2016, Martin Shain was indicted for making up a company that supposedly made these items for the Oregon University System. The majority of funds provided by Andrew Cuomo's Buffalo Billion program go to a factory for these items. As a result of the Majuro (MADGE-uh-roh) Declaration, the use of these items in Pacific countries like Tuvalu increased, and in 2012, the territory of Tokelau set a milestone in the use of these items. Despite receiving over 500 million dollars in government loans, a company that made these items from cylindrical components went bankrupt in 2011. Years after they were dismantled by Ronald Reagan, Barack Obama reinstalled these items on the White House roof. For 10 points, name these items that generate power from light.
tossups.answer: solar panels [or solar cells; or photovoltaic cells; or photovoltaic modules; or PV cells] <Shimizu>

tossups.question: In an opera set in this country, an offstage viola d'amore and a wordless chorus of sopranos and tenors play a plaintive melody as a woman keeps an all-night vigil. In a different opera, a royal procession in this country introduces the title character's "daughter-in-law elect," Katisha. A resident of this country threatens that he has "got a little list" of people he'd like to kill in his role as Lord High Executioner. The thought of a ship returning to this country after three years prompts a young woman to sing the aria "Un bel dì" in an opera in which news that Lieutenant Pinkerton has married Kate prompts Cio-Cio San (CHO-cho sahn) to commit ritual suicide. For 10 points, name this country, the setting of the operas Madama Butterfly and The Mikado.

While staying in this city, a man hears the story of Curran, a circus manager whose passion was founding a church exclusively for dogs. At the end of a novel set in this city, an old priest tells a girl "You can't conceive, my child, nor can I or anyone, the appalling strangeness of the mercy of God." This is the first place that Henry Pulling is taken to by Augusta in the novel Travels with My Aunt. In this city, Ida Arnold summons the police to the site of a mutual suicide pact where Rose's life is saved, but her husband jumps off a cliff. In a novel titled for a type of candy sold in this city, the journalist Fred Hale is murdered by gang leader Pinkie Brown. For 10 points, name this English seaside resort whose "rock" titles a novel by Graham Greene.

The most stable 18-electron complex prepared by reacting neutral iron metal with carbon monoxide has this geometry. Crystal field theory predicts this geometry's d-orbital splitting to have three levels: dxz and dyz degenerate in the lowest level, dxy and d-x-squared-y-squared in the middle level, and dz-squared fully anti-bonding in the highest level. Berry pseudorotation interchanges the two nonequivalent ligand environments in this geometry; those are axial and equatorial. Xenon difluoride has its central electron pairs arranged in this geometry. Compounds with a see-saw or T-shaped molecular geometry also have this electron-pair geometry. Compounds with this geometry have a central atom with dsp3 hybridization. For 10 points, name this molecular geometry taken by phosphorus pentafluoride.

This character's future husband accidentally forgets to take off a paper soldier hat while reading Friedrich Schiller's depiction of the death of Wallenstein to her. This character fails to tell her sister about a section of thin ice on a river in a chapter in which this character "meets Apollyon." She first meets one of her friends while hiding behind a curtain to avoid boys at Sallie Gardiner's New Year's Eve party. After inheriting her aunt's estate, Plumfield, this character converts it into a school with her husband, Professor Bhaer. This aspiring writer declines a marriage proposal from her neighbor, Laurie. For 10 points, name this tomboyish sister of Meg, Beth, and Amy in Louisa May Alcott's Little Women.
tossups.answer: Jo March [or Josephine March, or Josephine Bhaer; prompt on "March" or "Bhaer"] <Sy>

tossups.question: In 2009, a man in this country crashed his car into a parade in an attempt to hit a bus carrying the royal family. A ruler of this country was married to a prince accused of receiving a million dollar bribe from Lockheed. That queen here had daughters who controversially married the Carlist Duke of Parma and a former Hitler Youth member who became Prince Claus. In this country, Mohammed Bouyeri brutally murdered a director who made the film Submission about abused Muslim women. Its ruler abdicated in 2013, ending her 33-year reign. This country suffered over 1,800 deaths in a devastating 1953 flood. For 10 points, the film director Theo van Gogh was killed in what European country once ruled by Queen Beatrix?

The fourth part of this poem alludes to Dante's Paradiso in its description of "the perpetual star / Multifoliate rose." This poem imagines "lips that would kiss" that "form prayers to broken stone" in its third section, which begins "this is the dead land." It quotes Joseph Conrad's line "Life is very long" and fragments of the Lord's Prayer in its final section, which observes "between the idea / and the reality… falls the shadow." Its first stanza describes the title characters as "shape without form, shade without color, Paralysed force, gesture without motion." This poem's final lines are "This is the way the world ends / Not with a bang but a whimper." For 10 points, name this poem by T. S. Eliot whose title characters are spiritually empty.

This man arrested his second-in-command, William Burroughs, after the latter objected to a plan to go to the Isle of Terceira. He named an object in honor of his patron, Sir Christopher Hatton, whose crest was a female red deer. A legend states this man said he had plenty of time to finish a game of bowls at Plymouth Hoe before repelling invaders. He and John Norreys were responsible for a failed campaign that resulted in the loss of 20 ships. This captain of the Golden Hind "singed the beard" of a foreign king during his raid on Cádiz. He was the second-in-command of the fleet that resisted the so-called Invincible Armada of Spain. For 10 points, name this English sea captain who circumnavigated the world in the 1500's.

bonuses.leadin: The Biot–Savart (byoh-sah-VARR) law can be used to calculate the magnitude of this quantity produced by a current. For 10 points each:
answers: magnetic field [prompt on B or H]
vector potential [prompt on A; prompt on partial answer]
magnetization [or magnetic polarization; prompt on M] <Rombro>
parts: Name this quantity. The integral of this quantity over a closed loop equals mu-nought times the enclosed current according to Ampère's law.

For a vector field such as the magnetic field, the field can be decomposed into a sum in which one of the terms is the curl of this quantity. The gauge fixing condition for the Coulomb gauge requires the divergence of this quantity to be zero.
The B-field is equal to mu-nought times the quantity "H plus this value." It equals the magnetic dipole moment per unit volume, and its curl gives the current density.

bonuses.leadin: A paperboy in this village named Joe Crowell graduates at the top of his class at college, but dies in World War I. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this village, the setting of a play in which the Stage Manager narrates the lives of such people as Emily Webb and George Gibbs.
Grover's Corners is the setting of this Thornton Wilder play that typically uses no stage decorations or scenery during productions.

During the third act of Our Town, dialogue reveals that many characters have died in between the acts. This alcoholic has died after hanging himself in the attic. His epitaph is not words, but rather symbols.

bonuses.leadin: Robert Bemborough was killed in an engagement in this war that is often heralded as the prime example of medieval chivalry, the Combat of the Thirty. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this war fought between a member of the house of Montfort and the house of Blois. It ended after the Battle of Auray.
The War of the Breton Succession was a phase of this larger, very lengthy conflict that began when the British monarch Edward III instituted a claim to the French throne.
The sixth French monarch of this name defeated a Flemish uprising at the Battle of Cassel, but was less successful against the English in the Hundred Years' War, suffering defeats at Sluys and Crecy.

bonuses.leadin: Name these things about economist Daron Acemoğlu (DAH-roan AH-jem-OH-loo). For 10 points each:
parts: Acemoğlu's book Why Nations Fail compares inclusive institutions with oppressive institutions described by this term, such as North Korea.
Acemoğlu is currently employed by this university. Robert Solow and Paul Samuelson were two longtime faculty members at this university.

Acemoğlu's breakout paper claimed that countries that engaged in this practice only developed locations where diseases were relatively rare. Thus, European countries that engaged in this practice made few infrastructural developments in Central Africa.

bonuses.leadin: This character escapes after being shot in the leg and taken for dead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who desperately tries to warn the people of Sighet, shouting that he does not want money or pity but only to be listened to. He believes that God saved him so he could warn the villagers.
Moshe the Beadle appears in this acclaimed 1960 Holocaust memoir by Elie Wiesel.
This Italian Jewish author of The Periodic Table described his experience in the Auschwitz concentration camp in his Holocaust memoir If This Is a Man.

bonuses.leadin: Presence of this element may enhance binding of eIFF4 to mRNA IRE (I-R-E) sequences. For 10 points each:
answers: five-prime cap [or 7-methylguanylate cap; or m7G cap]
parts: Name this metal whose namesake response proteins bind to IRE sites in the transcripts of proteins involved in its metabolism, such as ferritin and the transferrin receptor.
An IRES (I-R-E-S) sequence permits translation independent of this post-transcriptional structure added to the end of mRNA. The initiation factor eIF4E binds to this 7-methyl-guanylate structure.

IRE1 (I-R-E-one) initiates this signaling pathway by unconventionally splicing XBP1 mRNA to yield a transcription factor that upregulates ERAD genes. PERK phosphorylates eIF2-alpha to halt the cell cycle in this process.

bonuses.leadin: Non-architectural feats by this man include his authorship of the satirical Latin verse comedy Philodoxius and his invention of the first polyalphabetic cipher. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian architect who wrote the first theoretical text on perspective, De Pictura, and updated a Vitruvius text in his Ten Books on Architecture.

Alberti's original design for the Basilica of Sant'Andrea in this city lacks a transept, dome, and choir. Giulio Romano both designed the Palazzo del Te, and painted the frescoes contained therein, in this northern Italian city.

Although Alberti proclaimed these building elements to be the most noble, they are completely absent from his design for the façade of San Sebastiano, also in Mantua. Alberti often used the colossal and Corinthian orders of these support structures in the facade of Sant'Andrea.

bonuses.leadin: In one myth, this deity created the world by breathing life into stones, but he fell short of his own standards so he destroyed his creations and had to repeat the process. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this god who supposedly disappeared from the world by walking on water westwards into the Pacific Ocean.
Viracocha was one of the chief gods revered by this South American civilization, who created representations of Viracocha at Ollantaytambo and Cuzco.

In a different story, Viracocha was the progenitor of the first Incan Manco Capac, whose most prized possession was a golden object of this type. A god named after this type of object is shown in the Gateway of the Sun in Tiwanaku and was worshiped by medieval residents of the Cook Islands.

bonuses.leadin: Name these composers who wrote pieces titled Symphony in C. For 10 points each:
parts: This composer was a student of Charles Gounod (goo-NOH) when he wrote his Symphony in C, which he suppressed due to similarities with his teacher's Symphony in D. He wrote the opera Carmen.
This highly self-critical composer published his Symphony in C, but destroyed all sketches of a planned second symphony. He wrote the ballet La Péri (pay-REE) and the opera Ariadne and Bluebeard.
This composer of a neoclassical Symphony in C also wrote the single-movement Symphonies of Wind Instruments as a memorial to Claude Debussy and omitted violins from his Symphony of Psalms.

bonuses.leadin: The longest-serving member of this group was Widjojo Nitisastro (wee-JOH-yo nee-tee-SASS-troh), who held office until 2001. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this group of American-educated economists in Indonesia. During the Suharto regime, they promoted the liberalization and deregulation of the country's economy.

The Berkeley Mafia is frequently compared to a similar group of economic advisers whose policies were adopted by Augusto Pinochet. That group was known as the "Boys" from this place, where they had studied.
Pinochet took power after a 1973 coup in this South American country.

bonuses.leadin: The first one of these things was built on Charter Hill at UC Berkeley. For 10 points each:
answers: hillside letters [or any other answer indicating that they are letters of the alphabet; or specific answers like rock letter or painted letter]
parts: Identify these mountainside geoglyphs common in the American West, where they are frequently erected to represent high schools or colleges. The University of Utah and Brigham Young University are both home to early examples of these.
The fourth hillside letter built was an M atop Mount Zion, built by and overlooking this state's School of Mines in its city of Golden.

Another hillside letter taking the shape of an M is atop Mount Sentinel overlooking this state's flagship university in Missoula. This state also has hillside M's in Butte and Bozeman to represent some of its other public universities.

bonuses.leadin: Signs of this painting's incompleteness include a lone foot next to an extremely small Saint Jerome, and only one column arising from several bases. For 10 points each:
answers: Madonna with the Long Neck [or Madonna and Child with Angels and St. Jerome; or any translation that mentions Madonna and a long neck]
Château de Fontainebleau [or Palace of Fontainebleau] <Shimizu>
parts: Name this painting whose title woman towers over five angels bearing gifts and holds an enormous baby Jesus on her lap.

Parmigianino's Madonna with the Long Neck and Bronzino's Venus, Cupid, Folly and Time are key examples of this artistic style that emerged between the Renaissance and Baroque, which employs serpentine poses and elongated body parts.

Francis I invited painters like Primaticcio and Rosso Fiorentino to decorate this building, which eventually lent its name to a separate school of Mannerism. This building was the original home of a Benvenuto Cellini sculpture of a nymph and a stag's head.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the Birch and Swinnerton–Dyer conjecture, for 10 points each.
answers: elliptic curves [do not prompt on or accept "ellipse"; do not accept or prompt on "elliptic functions"]
parts: The conjecture involves the rational points on these mathematical objects, which are used in cryptography. A correspondence between these objects and modular forms was the basis of the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture, a key ingredient in the proof of Fermat's last theorem.

The conjecture gives a specific value for the first coefficient of this series for an elliptic curve. This kind of power series, which includes Maclaurin series, is a local approximation of an analytic function with coefficients equal to the kth derivative of the function at some point divided by k-factorial.
The conjecture remains unresolved for groups for which this quantity is greater than one. For a matrix, this quantity is equal to the dimension of the vector space spanned by its columns.

bonuses.leadin: A recent "president" of both this movement and Nagriamel also served as her country's ambassador to Russia. For 10 points each:
answers: John Frum movement [or John Brum movement; prompt on cargo cults]
United States of America [or the USA; prompt on America]
parts: Name this movement that believes a certain figure will return on February 15. In regions like Tanna, followers of this movement built numerous landing strips and typically advocate rejecting Western culture.
The name "John Frum" may refer to someone named John, saying he is from this country. Many servicemen from this country were stationed in the Pacific during World War II to fight Japan.

The John Frum movement, like the Ghost Dance movement and the Heaven's Gate group, is this type of movement that predicts a major event that will totally transform society. Christians who follow such movements emphasize the reign of Jesus after the Second Coming.

bonuses.leadin: This event was coordinated with the Earl of Argyll's uprising in Scotland. For 10 points each:
answers: Monmouth Rebellion [or the Revolt of the West; or the West Country Rebellion]
parts: Name this 1685 revolt. After its failure, many participants were either executed or banished in the trials called the Bloody Assizes.
The target of the Monmouth Rebellion, James II, was eventually overthrown in the Glorious Revolution and replaced by this husband of Mary. He was the third English ruler with his name.
James and his predecessor, Charles II, were previously targeted in a 1683 plot in which conspirators planned to hide an ambushing force in this mansion.

bonuses.leadin: A central household in this novel is managed by a woman whose name means Splendid Phoenix. For 10 points each:
answers: Dream of the Red Chamber [or The Story of the Stone; or Hong Lou Meng]
Chinese [or Classical Chinese; or Literary Chinese; or vernacular Chinese; do not accept "Mandarin"]
parts: Name this novel in which the protagonist, born with a piece of jade in his mouth, is forced by his family into an arranged marriage, causing his cousin to waste away and die of grief.
Dream of the Red Chamber is one of the Four Great Classical Novels of this language. It was used to write Romance of the Three Kingdoms.
Near the end of the novel, Baoyu is guided through a dream by this type of person, whom Baoyu is destined to accompany. Earlier, this type of person had given a prized golden locket to Baochai.

bonuses.leadin: This reaction involves the reductive condensation of alpha-bromo-esters with ketones or aldehydes to generate beta-hydroxy-esters. For 10 points each:
answers: proton [or hydrogen; or H-plus; or H]
parts: Name this reaction whose first step involves oxidative addition of zinc into the alpha carbon–halogen bond.

After that first step, an ester enolate is generated, which is the nucleophile in the reaction. Enolates are usually generated by the removal or migration of this group from a carbonyl compound in a tautomerization step.
Ester enolates more commonly react with other esters to generate beta-keto-esters in this reaction. Its intramolecular variant is called the Dieckmann condensation.

bonuses.leadin: The character who gives this speech declares that "he which hath no stomach to this fight" may have their "passport made." For 10 points each:
answers: St. Crispin's Day speech from Henry V
"Once more unto the breach, dear friends" [do not accept other answers] <Sy>
parts: Name this speech whose speaker imagines his soldiers standing "a tip-toe" in years to come while others "hold their manhoods cheap." It is given to rouse the English army before a battle against the French.
The St. Crispin's Day speech is given before the Battle of Agincourt by the title monarch in Henry V, a history play by this author.
The third act of Henry V opens with Henry giving a speech at the siege of Harfleur, which begins with these seven words.

bonuses.leadin: After this man's death, thousands of people received tours of the crime scene, where they saw a bloody mattress next to a wall filled with bullet holes, as seen in a famous photograph. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Black Panther leader from Illinois killed in a 1969 police raid. He coined the phrase "rainbow coalition," which was later used by a Jesse Jackson organization.
Fred Hampton's death was a direct result of this organization's program COINTELPRO, which was overseen by director J. Edgar Hoover.

After the death of Fred Hampton, this group issued a "declaration of a state of war." This group, which bombed buildings across the country, was originally a faction of Students for a Democratic Society.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about people's heads randomly catching on fire in Roman mythology, for 10 points each.
parts: Tanaquil selected this son of the servant Ocrisia as the next king of Rome in part because of a fiery halo around his head. In some stories, Tanaquil also arranges his conception by a ghostly phallus that rose out of the palace hearth.
Aeneas claims to have seen his son's head harmlessly burst into flames while recounting his escape from Troy at the court of this queen of Carthage, who falls in love with him.
The only moment in the Aeneid to feature this daughter of Latinus is when her hair catches on fire as an omen. This future wife of Aeneas was originally promised to Turnus.

bonuses.leadin: A character with this occupation is married to a woman who carves figurines of Noah's Ark and his animals. For 10 points each:
parts: Name the occupation of the husband of Trina, who wins five thousand dollars in a lottery. He ultimately meets his end alongside Marcus in Death Valley.
That dentist is the title character of this Frank Norris novel. The final image of this novel is of the title character handcuffed to Marcus' corpse in the sweltering desert.
Frank Norris' 1901 novel The Octopus is about the clash between wheat farmers and this industry, a mode of transportation also prominently seen in the novel Atlas Shrugged.
